Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: An inclusive phylogeny for the Pseudoxyrhophiine snakes in Madagascar: understanding causes of species diversification
Award.AbstractNarration:
This study will examine processes that lead to the diversification of species -- in number, form and ecology. First, a phylogeny of the Madagascar pseudoxyrhophiine snakes will be produced. This highly diverse group of vertebrates, with more than 130 species, occurs in arboreal, terrestrial, fossorial, and aquatic habitats, as well as tropical rainforests, mountain forests, swamps, grasslands and deserts. Using Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) techniques to generate hundreds of genes, the first comprehensive phylogeny of this snake group will be produced. Second, the phylogeny will be integrated with morphological and ecological data (including remotely-sensed data and GIS), in a computationally intense framework, to reveal how species, ecology and morphology evolve together over time and to examine the processes associated with adaptive radiations.

This project will also train undergraduates, doctoral students, and a postdoctoral researcher. Results will be widely communicated to the public via the American Museum of Natural History's Science Bulletin, CUNY's TV Program "Study with the Best", and other formats. In addition to revealing complex evolutionary processes, results of this research will also have valuable conservation applications for this group of snakes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With 3% of the worlds? biodiversity, Madagascar is significant among all large islands showing that most of the diversity is found and evolved only there (endemic). As opposed to the complexity of continental faunas, Madagascar offers a unique opportunity to understand how mega-diverse regions originate in a much more controlled environment, thus serving as a natural laboratory for studying evolution. Unfortunately, for most organisms where a complete fossil record is unknown, it is therefore unclear how modern species originated and diversified in Madagascar. Here we examined the origins and diversification of the gemsnakes (Pseudoxyrhophiinae), a group of snakes found only on Madagascar and diversifying into most niches generating ecologies and morphologies often seen among large continental fauna. Adaptive radiation theory predicts how species will colonize and diversify in regions. One of the major expectations from adaptive radiation theory predicts that upon colonization the rate at which species evolved is expected to be high and reduced as niches are filled by competing taxa. However, we demonstrate with a nearly complete evolutionary tree composed of 732 samples using genomic data that extremely diverse communities can evolve under steady, constant rates of speciation. Therefore, we underscore that these predictions about the tempo of diversification from adaptive radiation theory may be in error. We also show that the Pleistocene Epoch so dominated by glacial cycles and known to dampen rates of speciation in some animals in the Northern Hemisphere, also uniquely changed environments in Madagascar and also reduced speciation rates of snakes there. We have also shown for the first time that dentition and arboreal habitats are correlated over evolutionary time, where arboreal taxa likely use rear fangs to hold prey. Importantly, this research helped fun three long expeditions to Madagascar providing hundreds of samples accessible to other researchers and has led to the discovery of 38 new species of snakes in Madagascar.

The research has also allowed us to combine genomic data for all snakes and lizards (squamates) to generate the most comprehensive evolutionary tree of these animals. This tree was used to understand the timing of origin of all squamates and correct problematic taxonomies that have puzzled researchers for more than one century.

This grant has supported the research of one female Ph.D. student focusing on speciation of snakes in Madagascar, an African American male?s postdoctoral research on the evolution of cranial anatomy in these snakes, one American Museum of Natural History (AMNH) Helen Fellow (female postgrad computer programmer) and associated six Brown Scholars (six female high school computer programmers), and two SRMP (Science Research and Mentoring Program) high school students.
